abstract.p: David L Meth letter on May 3 article deplores Japan's neglect of its bilingual and bicultural people who return from living abroad

block.p: Japan's lack of acceptance of Japanese who return from living abroad (front page, May 3) reflects a society rich in culture and tradition that is stuck in a postwar mentality. The neglect of what could be Japan's finest international resource -- its bilingual and bicultural people -- is disabling Japan because the leaders of Japanese business and government who do not communicate well to their own people don't communicate well to the rest of the world.

Japan's lack of acceptance of Japanese who return from living abroad (front page, May 3) reflects a society rich in culture and tradition that is stuck in a postwar mentality. The neglect of what could be Japan's finest international resource -- its bilingual and bicultural people -- is disabling Japan because the leaders of Japanese business and government who do not communicate well to their own people don't communicate well to the rest of the world.

The young Japanese are losing their identity, and the elders refuse to change even slightly, clinging to the past and destroying the nation's growth. It is no surprise, therefore, that the young Japanese are choosing to remain abroad or leave Japan for more freedom of expression and creativity, and respect for individual effort.
DAVID L. METH Greenwich, Conn., May 3, 2000
The writer is president of the United States-Japan Language and Culture Institute.
